title: Seder-Masochism
text:
Seder-Masochism is a 2018 American <a href="animation">animated</a> <a href="musical%20film">musical</a> <a href="List%20of%20films%20based%20on%20the%20Bible">biblical</a> <a href="comedy-drama">comedy-drama</a> film written, directed, produced and animated by American artist <a href="Nina%20Paley">Nina Paley</a>. The film reinterprets the <a href="Book%20of%20Exodus">Book of Exodus</a>, especially stories associated with the <a href="Passover%20Seder">Passover Seder</a>, such as the <a href="Plagues%20of%20Egypt">death of the Egyptian first-born</a>, and <a href="Moses">Moses</a> leading the <a href="Israelites">Israelites</a> out of slavery in Egypt. The film depicts these events against a backdrop of widespread worship of the <a href="Mother%20goddess">Great Mother Goddess</a>, showing the rise of patriarchy.
"Seder-Masochism" is Paley's second feature film, following "<a href="Sita%20Sings%20the%20Blues">Sita Sings the Blues</a>" in 2008, an animated film loosely based on the "<a href="Ramayana">Ramayana</a>". In a similar fashion to her previous work, Paley mainly uses previously published music in "Seder-Masochism", with popular and liturgical songs ranging from 1928 to 2018. She also draws from spoken voice recordings she made in 2011 with her father, Hiram Paley, who is placed in the role of the traditional Hebrew deity. Greg Sextro served as <a href="sound%20designer">sound designer</a> on the film.
With <a href="Theodore%20Gray">Theodore Gray</a>, Paley formed PaleGray Labs to create a method for animating <a href="embroidery">embroidery</a>, which they call "embroidermation". In "Seder-Masochism", embroidered animation is the basis for one scene: "Chad Gadya".
Debuting in the 2018 film festival season, "Seder-Masochism" was reviewed positively, with Paley's bright and satirical style compared to <a href="Monty%20Python">Monty Python</a> and others. The film earned the Audience Award at the <a href="ANIMATOR%20%28festival%29">ANIMATOR</a> film festival in <a href="Poland">Poland</a>.
Plot.
The <a href="Book%20of%20Exodus">Book of Exodus</a> is retold by <a href="Moses">Moses</a>, his brother <a href="Aaron">Aharon</a>, the <a href="Destroying%20angel%20%28Bible%29">Angel of Death</a>, <a href="Jesus">Jesus</a>, and the traditional <a href="Yahweh">Hebrew God</a>. The ancient <a href="mother%20goddess">mother goddess</a> is cast in a "tragic struggle" against the new patriarchy.
Production.
After "Sita Sings the Blues", Paley was criticized by some observers for co-opting the <a href="culture%20of%20India">culture of India</a> as an outsider, an assertion with which she strongly disagreed. A recurring theme among the negative comments was "how would you like it if people made a film about your religion?" Paley thought that she would enjoy watching any such film. Accepting this as a challenge, she turned to her own <a href="Jewish%20culture">Jewish cultural heritage</a> for her next project: a revisionist retelling of the story of <a href="Passover">Passover</a>. She pored over the Book of Exodus, finding details that were not part of modern Jewish culture, for instance, that Moses's brother Aharon performed some of the acts that are commonly attributed to Moses, and that the Jews were killing each other during their 40 years "wandering" in the desert. For inspiration, she also read "<a href="The%20Creation%20of%20Patriarchy">The Creation of Patriarchy</a>" by <a href="Gerda%20Lerner">Gerda Lerner</a>, and "The Language of the Goddess" by <a href="Marija%20Gimbutas">Marija Gimbutas</a>. She concluded that the Book of Exodus represents the final defeat of goddess worship by the <a href="patriarchy">patriarchy</a> that had been rising since the <a href="Neolithic%20Revolution">agricultural revolution</a>.
In 2011, Paley interviewed her terminally ill father, Hiram, intending that his voice would serve as the old bearded god figure of the Israelites. For herself, she chose to play the part of a sacrificial goat, because <a href="animal%20sacrifice">animal sacrifice</a> was essential to many early religions, and because she has been seen as the <a href="black%20sheep">black sheep</a> of her family. Hiram Paley died in 2012 at the age of 78. Even though her father was a <a href="Jews">Jewish</a> <a href="Atheism">atheist</a>, the Paley family had celebrated Passover every year so that the children would know their cultural identity. Paley, also a Jewish atheist, weaves the voice recordings of her father into the film as a way to understand the Passover story.
In September 2011, Paley initiated a <a href="Kickstarter">Kickstarter</a> crowd-funding effort to raise money for "Phase I" of the film, with a goal of $3,600. The campaign brought in $4,146. The intent of Phase I was to make recordings of various family Passover Seder discussions. Ultimately, the project took another direction, and the recordings were not used in the film.
Paley worked on the project over the course of six years, spending about three-and-a-half years animating and producing it. First, she animated some musical numbers – "This Land Is Mine" and "Moses-Exodus" – using <a href="Adobe%20Flash%23Macromedia">Macromedia Flash 8</a> running on a first-generation <a href="Mac%20Pro">Mac Pro</a> tower, but this was not powerful enough to edit <a href="4K%20resolution">4K resolution</a> video in a practical manner. In 2013, she shifted the project to a second-generation Mac Pro, the vertical cylinder model, and settled on the application <a href="Moho%20%28Anime%20Studio%29">Anime Studio Pro</a>. Paley initially found the Anime Studio Pro interface to be frustratingly complex, so she hosted Chilean animator Victor Paredes at her workspace for a week in 2014 to better learn the software. In 2016, Anime Studio Pro became Moho Pro, with an upgraded version. Paley said that it was not until 2017 that she could express herself easily in Moho Pro.
In November 2017, Paley wrote that much of the project had been completed without a "coherent story", despite the attempt to tie it together in the loose form of a Passover Seder. She decided instead "to articulate the Exodus from the Goddesses' point of view", the goddesses who were at that time worshiped in Egypt as <a href="Hathor">Hathor</a>, <a href="Isis">Isis</a>, <a href="Nut%20%28goddess%29">Nut</a>, <a href="Sekhmet">Sekhmet</a>, and others. This turned her film into a narrative "about patriarchy and the suppression of the Goddess".
After showing rough cuts of the new concept to friends, Paley decided to bring more goddess images into the film. In late 2017/early 2018, she imported high-resolution photos of ancient goddess figurines into the graphics editor <a href="GIMP">GIMP</a> to remove backgrounds, then she exported the resulting <a href="Portable%20Network%20Graphics">PNG files</a> to Moho. In Moho, Paley assigned "little skeleton" points on the images to establish how the goddess figurines could bend, and she created additional layers for smaller movements such as eye blinks and smiling/frowning. She offered these individual goddess animations for free on her blog. Among the goddess figurines appearing in the film are the <a href="Seated%20Woman%20of%20%C3%87atalh%C3%B6y%C3%BCk">Seated Woman of Çatalhöyük</a> (6,000 BC, Turkey), the <a href="Venus%20of%20Willendorf">Venus of Willendorf</a> (30,000 BC, Austria), and the <a href="Venus%20of%20Hohle%20Fels">Venus of Hohle Fels</a> (35,000 BC, Germany).
The final assembly and editing of the film were performed on <a href="Final%20Cut%20Pro%20X">Final Cut Pro X</a>, which Paley said was "horrible" in its interface but powerful in its processing of 4K video: 3840×2160 pixels. In all, Paley estimated the film's final budget at $20,000.
Embroidery animation.
Paley teamed with science writer and programmer <a href="Theodore%20Gray">Theodore Gray</a> to develop "embroidermation": an automated method of animating <a href="embroidery">embroidery</a>. In 2015 after working for a year and a half, the PaleGray Labs team produced a Passover-themed animated short, "Chad Gadya", intended to serve as <a href="intermission">intermission</a> for "Seder-Masochism". Paley created animated figures in Macromedia Flash 8, then Gray imported the resulting vector files into <a href="Wolfram%20Mathematica">Wolfram Mathematica</a>, a powerful visualization program which he co-created. The figures were rendered as polygons in Mathematica, then a custom application was written to properly align the embroidery stitch direction, different for each polygon. Using an embroidery machine, a total of 516 embroidered figures were stitched into 86 matzoh covers (decorative cloths for holding <a href="matzo">matzo</a>h during Passover), then each completed figure was photographed to create one frame of animation. The "Chad Gadya" scene runs just under 3 minutes, accompanied by the children's Passover song, "<a href="Chad%20Gadya">Chad Gadya</a>", sung by <a href="Moishe%20Oysher">Moishe Oysher</a> and recorded in the 1950s.
Release.
When the film was complete, Paley determined to wait until it had been screened at film festivals before she offered the film for free online in the same manner as "Sita Sings the Blues". Earlier, she uploaded some scenes-in-progress to <a href="Vimeo">Vimeo</a> and <a href="YouTube">YouTube</a>, including the opening "God-Mother" number in 2017, and "Death of the Firstborn Egyptians" in 2014, the latter gaining 2.7 million views by August 2020. The scene "This Land Is Mine" was first posted in 2012, and by 2014 had received 10 million views, with more viewers added during every news cycle highlighting the <a href="Israeli%E2%80%93Palestinian%20conflict">Israeli–Palestinian conflict</a>.
Public domain dedication.
On January 24, 2019, Paley dedicated the film to the <a href="public%20domain">public domain</a>, releasing it under a <a href="CC0">CC0</a> license, and uploading the master files to the <a href="Internet%20Archive">Internet Archive</a>. Paley clarified that the music used in the film was still copyrighted by its original authors, and this was one of the reasons she had no plans to pursue commercial distribution of the film.
Reception.
Following June 2018 showing at <a href="Annecy%20International%20Animated%20Film%20Festival">Annecy International Animated Film Festival</a>, "<a href="The%20Hollywood%20Reporter">The Hollywood Reporter</a>" wrote that the film was "completely irreverent, occasionally hilarious and politically evocative", and that it "defies definition" with its different aspects of <a href="Musical%20theatre">musical comedy</a>, psychedelic cartoon, and "insolent" religious epic. Paley is observed to have "lots of fun" turning Bible events "into <a href="Busby%20Berkeley">Busby Berkeley</a>-style song-and-dance numbers." Spain's <a href="El%20Mundo%20%28Spain%29">"El Mundo"</a> newspaper compared the film's irony and apparent naïveté to works by the <a href="Marx%20Brothers">Marx Brothers</a>, Italian playwright <a href="Dario%20Fo">Dario Fo</a>, and <a href="Monty%20Python">Monty Python</a>, writing that Paley applies unprejudiced and sharp commentary to the Jewish story while remaining bright and ridiculous. French film website "Courte-Focale" compared "Seder-Masochism" to "<a href="Monty%20Python%27s%20Life%20of%20Brian">Monty Python's Life of Brian</a>", writing that Paley brought a "fiercely humorous" spirit to the task of attacking patriarchal religion, an attack carried out with "acuteness and precision" in a way that disarms her opponents and yields a hilarious result. Greek animator Vassilis Kroustallis said that Paley's second film "is another bold attempt... to associate the catastrophe that religion may bring with the male ego." He wrote that the musical choreography is good but the editing suffers from the juxtaposition of different scenes. "<a href="Variety%20%28magazine%29">Variety</a>" wrote that the film was "delightfully impudent" and inventive, despite being "episodic and uneven" in its presentation as a series of short scenes.
In <a href="Pozna%C5%84">Poznań</a>, Poland, at the <a href="ANIMATOR%20%28festival%29">ANIMATOR</a> film festival, "Seder-Masochism" earned the Audience Award for Feature Film.
Music.
Paley spent $70,000 to secure the music rights to "Sita Sings the Blues", just to distribute it freely, so for "Seder-Masochism" she turned to the <a href="Fair%20use%23Parody">parody defense in fair use</a>: a parody of a copyrighted work can be considered fair use. As a result, she did not try to secure the rights to the many recordings she used in the film. She told "Variety" that anyone who is interested can perform the legal work to clear the music rights, after which that person or corporation will be able to distribute the film commercially or license it for distribution.
The song "This Land Is Mine" came first in Paley's production process; she used it to frame a scene in which a succession of warring men claims the <a href="Holy%20Land">Holy Land</a> as theirs. The music is the main theme of the 1960 film <a href="Exodus%20%281960%20film%29">"Exodus"</a>, composed by Austrian <a href="Ernest%20Gold%20%28composer%29">Ernest Gold</a>, with words added later by <a href="Pat%20Boone">Pat Boone</a>, which he sang and released as a single titled "The Exodus Song". Boone, an American Christian, said he wrote the lyrics in 25 minutes on Christmas Eve, on the back of a Christmas card, which he later sent to <a href="Yad%20Vashem">Yad Vashem</a>, the Holocaust memorial in Jerusalem. The version Paley used in "Seder-Masochism" is a cover by Boone's friend <a href="Andy%20Williams">Andy Williams</a>, released in 1962 under the title "The Exodus Song (This Land Is Mine)", as part of his album "<a href="Moon%20River%20and%20Other%20Great%20Movie%20Themes">Moon River and Other Great Movie Themes</a>", the album reaching number 3 on the <a href="Billboard%20200">"Billboard" Top 200</a>, selling more than two million copies by 1967. In the 1960s, the song became a <a href="Zionism">Zionist</a> anthem. Paley parodies the song's Zionist theme to show the senselessness of war in the Middle East: the scene ends in atomic destruction, with nobody winning except the Angel of Death.
Paley commissioned a song for the film from New York-based rock musician Todd Michaelsen, who had earlier collaborated on a song for "Sita Sings the Blues", but Paley eventually decided not to use Michaelsen's song. She said that she prefers "songs that have a different original meaning", so that her animation adds a second meaning, yielding greater depth.
For her dancing goddesses number, animated in early 2018, Paley chose a song from the 1976 film "<a href="Car%20Wash%20%28film%29">Car Wash</a>": "You Gotta Believe", written by <a href="Norman%20Whitfield">Norman Whitfield</a> and performed by <a href="the%20Pointer%20Sisters">the Pointer Sisters</a>, using <a href="Rose%20Royce">Rose Royce</a> as the backing band. In "Car Wash", Paley said the song is used to "urge activist men to stand up for their activist sisters", but in "Seder-Masochism" it is an ultimately unsuccessful plea to Moses to embrace goddess worship.
